case_name: Firm Anwar Khan Mehboob Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Petitioner is a partnership firm named Anwarkhan Mehboob and Co., Jabalpur, that manufactures and sells bidis.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a partnership firm which manufactures and sells, bidis, under the name and style of Anwarkhan Mehboob and Co., Jabalpur.

facts.text: In 1948, petitioner firm acquired right to pluck and carry away tendu leaves from 99 villages in former Imlai Estate for 25 years (1948-1973) from Malguzar Raja Raghuraj Singh for Rs. 9,000 per year.

anchor.surface_text: In 1948 the petitioner firm, with a view to securing a supply of tendu leaves over the years acquired for a term of 25 years, the right to pluck and carry away tendu leaves from plants in ninety-nine villages in the former Imlai Estate from the Malguzar Raja Raghuraj Singh.

facts.text: Agreement document executed by Raja Raghuraj Singh on August 22, 1948, registered as annexure I.

anchor.surface_text: The period of 25 years was to run from 1948 to 1973. The document, which was number registered  annexure I , was executed by the Raja on August 22, 1948.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals and Alienated Lands) Act No. 1 of 1951 passed in 1950, vesting all proprietary rights in the State.

anchor.surface_text: In 1950 the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals and Alienated Lands  Act  No. 1 of 1951  was passed. Under the Act  ,which may be briefly called the Abolition Act  all rights,. title and interest vesting in the proprietor...

facts.text: Government of Madhya Pradesh obstructed persons holding contracts for tendu leaves, including petitioner firm.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madhya Pradesh obstructed the persons who held companytracts for tendu leaves Jac, wood, timber or other forest produce, including the petitioner firm,

facts.text: Petitioner firm filed Writ Petition No. 309 of 1951 under Art. 32, heard with dozen others, decided on December 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner firm and many others petitioned to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution... that of the petitioner being W. P. No. 309 of 1951  Firm Anwar Khan Mehboob Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh , and were decided on December 23, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Chhotabhai Jethabhai v. State of MP (1953 SCR 476) held contracts like petitioner's are licenses not extinguished by Abolition Act, issued writ of prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The main judgment of this Court was pronounced in a petition filed by one Chhotabhai Jethabhai and is reported in Chhotabhai Jethabhai v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1 . A Divisional Bench of this Court held that companytracts and agreements...

facts.text: Petitioner firm obtained writ of prohibition in 1952 case, allowing enjoyment of agreement till 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner firm, in companymon with the other petitioners, on that occasion obtained a writ of prohibition also. It would have enjoyed the fruits of its agreement with the Raja till the year 1973

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Vyapar Viniyaman Adhiniyam, 1964 (No. 29 of 1964) passed to regulate trade in tendu leaves by creating State monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: In 1964 the Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta  Vyapar Viniyaman  Adhiniyam, 1964  29 of 1964 ,  companyveniently called the Adhiniyam  was passed, as the preamble openly professes to make provision for regulating...

facts.text: Adhiniyam divides areas into units, appoints agents, fixes prices, requires registration, imposes restrictions on purchase/transport under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: The Adhiniyam companyferred power on the State Government to divide specified arm into units, to appoint its own agents for purchase and trade in tendu leaves... Section 5 of the Adhiniyam provides...

facts.text: Imlai Estate divided into unit No. 3 Baghraji, unit No. 5 Kundam, unit No. 11 Umaria leased areas.

anchor.surface_text: The Imlai Estate, in respect of which the petitioner firm held its agreement, was divided up into unit No. 3 Baghraji leased area, unit No. 5 Kundam leased area, and unit No. 11 Umaria leased area.

facts.text: State Government invited tenders for units including the three, noting leased to petitioner till 1973; no tenders for 5 and 11, one for 3.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government then invited tenders for the areas including the three units but the remarks companyumn showed that these units were leased by the Malguzar to the petitioner firm up to the year 1973. No tenders were received for units 5 and 1 1 but there was a tender for unit 3.

facts.text: On March 20, 1965, Minister for Forests informed petitioner firm's representatives that leases extinguished by Adhiniyam, extended time for tenders.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1965 the Minister for Forests in a meeting, informed the representatives of the petitioner firm that their leases stood extinguished by reason of the Adhiniyam and that time was extended...

facts.text: On March 23, 1965, tenders for unit 3 Baghraji and unit 11 Umaria accepted.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1965 tenders made by two persons in respect of unit 3  Baghraji  and unit 11  Umaria  were accepted

facts.text: On March 24, 1965, Divisional Forest Officer, Jabalpur informed petitioner firm by letter that right to collect tendu leaves in 99 villages abrogated under Adhiniyam.

anchor.surface_text: and the Next day the petitioner firm was informed, by letter from the Divisional Forest Officer, Jabalpur Division, that the right to companylect tendu leaves in all the 99 villages of Imlai Estate was abrogated by the State Government under the Adhiniyam.

facts.text: Present case is Writ Petition No. 38 of 1965 under Art. 32 in original jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 38 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitioner claims 1952 decision recognizes property right, res judicata, and Adhiniyam does not apply due to Expl. I s.5.

anchor.surface_text: His first companytention was that the Adhiniyam did number touch the rights of the petitioner firm as recognized... He claimed that the petitioner firm was entitled to move this Court...

facts.text: Respondent contends no property right, 1952 decision dissented from later, Adhiniyam applies to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State the learned Attorney-General companytended that there was numberright in property which companyld be claimed... the petitioner firm was as much affected by s. 5 of the Adhiniyam as any other person

facts.text: Court holds 1952 Chhotabhai decision per incuriam, not binding precedent, no res judicata as cause of action different.

anchor.surface_text: That ruling must be held number binding... the decision in Chhotabhai Jethabhais case 1 , which treated the agreements as bare licences... was apparently given per incuriam... The cause of action is entirely distinct.

facts.text: Court finds petitioner's rights are bare licenses, not property rights; Adhiniyam validly creates monopoly applying to petitioner; petition fails.

anchor.surface_text: Since there is numberright to property before the leaves are plucked, numbersuch rights can be said to be invaded by the Adhiniyam... The petition must, therefore, fail.

facts.text: In Shantabai v. State of Bombay (1959 SCR 265), Supreme Court did not follow Chhotabhai, held no property right in unregistered agreements.

anchor.surface_text: In Shantabai v. State of Bombay 2  petitions similar to those in Chhotabhai Jethabhais case 1  met a different fate... Chhotabhai Jethabhais case was cited... but it was number followed.

facts.text: In Mahadeo v. State of Bombay (1959 Supp 2 SCR 339), Constitution Bench held such rights contractual licenses ending with proprietor's title.

anchor.surface_text: Mahadeos case  3  took the same view of Chhotabhai Jethabhais 1  case. The Constitution Bench declined to accept that such rights were property rights
ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 38 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

The petitioner firm and many others petitioned to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution... that of the petitioner being W. P. No. 309 of 1951  Firm Anwar Khan Mehboob Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh , and were decided on December 23, 1952.
A petit-ion under Art. 32 of the Constitution was moved in this Court but it failed. Chhotabhai Jethabhais case was cited... but it was number followed.

In 1950 the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals and Alienated Lands  Act  No. 1 of 1951  was passed. Under the Act  ,which may be briefly called the Abolition Act  all rights,. title and interest vesting in the proprietor...

Purchase of tendu leaves from the State Government or the aforesaid Government officer or agent shall number be deemed to be a purchase in companytravention of the provisions of this Act.

arguments.claim: Res judicata does not apply due to different cause of action

anchor.surface_text: We may begin by considering the correctness of the contention that the earlier decision operates as res judicata in this case... The cause of action is entirely distinct.

arguments.claim: Agreements are bare licenses coupled with grant, terminable with licensor's title; no property right

anchor.surface_text: the agreements then considered betokened a licence coupled with a grant. The petitioner firm like the others had a licence to go to the forests to pick and carry away tendu leaves but had no other right.

arguments.claim: s.5 of Adhiniyam creates state monopoly in tendu leaves trade, prohibiting purchase/transport except by govt/agent

anchor.surface_text: The core of the problem thus is what is the effect of the Adhiniyam upon the rights of the petitioner firm... no person shall purchase or transport tendu leaves except the State Government or officer...

arguments.claim: No right to property before leaves plucked; Adhiniyam invades no fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: Since there is no right to property before the leaves are plucked, no such rights can be said to be invaded by the Adhiniyam.

arguments.claim: Shantabai and Mahadeo cases correctly hold no property right in such unregistered agreements/licenses

anchor.surface_text: In Shantabai v. State of Bombay petitions similar to those in Chhotabhai Jethabhais case met a different fate... Mahadeos case took the same view...

holdings.text: The decision in Chhotabhai Jethabhais case was given per incuriam and is not binding precedent.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, laid down that the decision in Chhotabhai Jethabhais case 1 , which treated the agreements as bare licences and yet considered that a fundamental right to property was conferred by them, was apparently given per incuriam and could not therefore be followed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court followed Shantabai and Mahadeo which dissented from Chhotabhai for failing to notice that bare licenses end with licensor's title and do not confer property rights; omitted key legal aspects.

holdings.text: The earlier 1952 decision does not operate as res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: We may begin by considering the correctness of the contention that the earlier decision operates as res judicata in this case. The history of the ruling in Chhotabhai Jethabhais case 1  is wellknown.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different cause of action (Abolition Act interference vs. Adhiniyam monopoly); per incuriam nature; distinguished Hoystead as not applicable to new statute creating new circumstances.

holdings.text: The agreements confer bare licenses coupled with a grant to pluck tendu leaves, terminable with the licensor's title; no independent right to property exists before leaves are plucked.

anchor.surface_text: This was not the true position in law because the agreements then considered betokened a licence coupled with a grant. The petitioner firm like the others had a licence to go to the forests to pick and carry away tendu leaves but had no other right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Shantabai and Mahadeo: unregistered agreements are licenses ending on extinction of proprietor's title under Abolition Act; no property right in unsevered produce.

holdings.text: Section 5 of the Adhiniyam applies to the petitioner firm and abrogates its rights under the 1948 agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The core of the problem thus is what is the effect of the Adhiniyam upon the rights of the petitioner firm under the agreement it had obtained from Raja ? For this purpose, we have to go to the terms of s. 5

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 prohibits purchase/transport except by govt/agent; Explanation I does not save petitioner as it did not purchase from govt; monopoly vests exclusive rights in state post-Abolition Act.

holdings.text: Explanation I to s.5 does not exempt the petitioner firm; it must purchase tendu leaves from the government like others.

anchor.surface_text: The position of the petitioner firm is this it does not seek to justify its acquisition of tendu leaves by reason of a purchasefrom Government. It says that it has already purchased the tendu leaves from the Raja

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation I deems govt purchases non-contravening, but petitioner claims pre-existing right, not govt purchase; must comply with monopoly.

holdings.text: The Adhiniyam invades no fundamental right to property, rendering the Art.32 petition not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: Since there is no right to property before the leaves are plucked, no such rights can be said to be invaded by the Adhiniyam. It cannot be said either by reason of any rule of res judicata

holdings.reasoning_summary: No property right in unplucked leaves or licenses; contracts not property; no res judicata saves claim.

holdings.text: The petition fails as the petitioner possesses no right of property invocable under Art.32.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bare contractual license, not property; Adhiniyam creates valid monopoly without invading rights.

precedents.citation: Chhotabhai Jethabhai v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Chhotabhai Jethabhai v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1 1953 S. C. R. 476. A Divisional Bench of this Court held that contracts and agreements, such as the one held by the petitioner firm, were in essence and effect licenses granted to the transferees to cut, gather and carry away, the produce in the shape of tends leaves, lac, or timber or wood.

precedents.case_name: Chhotabhai Jethabhai v State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Contracts and agreements for plucking tendu leaves, lac, timber etc. are licences not extinguished by the Abolition Act; State cannot interfere with such rights
precedents.cited_holding: Writ of prohibition issued prohibiting State from interfering with enjoyment of rights under such contracts

anchor.surface_text: Shantabai v. State of Bombay 2 1959 S. C. R. 265. petitions similar to those in Chhotabhai Jethabhai's case 1 met a different fate. Shantabai, who claimed the benefit of Art. 19 1 f and g had been given a right by her husband to take and appropriate all kinds of wood from his Zamindari forests.

precedents.cited_proposition: Unregistered agreement conferring right to take wood from zamindari forests does not create property right protected under Art. 19; Chhotabhai case not followed

anchor.surface_text: Mahadeo v. State of Bombay 3 1959 Supp. 2 S. C. R. 339 at 343. we may quote from that case. Speaking of the unregistered agreement, it was said if it conferred a part or share in the proprietary right, or even a right to profit a prendre- i needed registration to convey the right.

precedents.cited_proposition: Agreements like in Chhotabhai are bare licences ending with licensor's title or contractual rights not property; no fundamental right violated; Chhotabhai per incuriam
precedents.cited_holding: Petitions under Art. 32 dismissed as no breach of fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: Mohanlal Hargovind v. C.I.T. 2 1949 I.T. R. 473 P. C. to find out the nature of the agreements. The Judicial Committee was discussing the matter to find out whether the amounts spent in buying tendu leaves, which were the raw materials for manufacture of bidis, became capital expenditure simply because crops of a number of years were presently purchased.

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment for purchase of tendu leaves crops is revenue account not capital as no interest in land obtained

anchor.surface_text: Hoystead v. Commissioner of Taxation 2 1926 A. C. 155. that such a fundamental fact cannot, in a fresh litigation, be allowed to be ignored. He submitted that it was open to the Government to have demurred to the claim on the ground that no right of property was invaded, but it did not.

precedents.cited_proposition: Assumption of fundamental fact in earlier decision cannot be ignored in fresh litigation on same cause of action

precedents.citation: Society of Medical Officers of Health v. Hope 2

anchor.surface_text: Society of Medical Officers of Health v. Hope 2 1960 A. C. 551. but was not followed. It may also be mentioned that in the volume which contains Hoystead's case there is to be found another case of the Judicial Committee Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited v. Municipal Council of Broken Hill 3

precedents.case_name: Society of Medical Officers of Health v Hope

precedents.citation: Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited v. Municipal Council of Broken Hill 3

anchor.surface_text: Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited v. Municipal Council of Broken Hill 3 1926 A. C. 94. which seems to be in conflict with Hoystead's case 1 . It was argued before the House of Lords that Hoystead's case 1 was wrongly decided. The House did not pronounce their opinion on this submission but noted the fact that there was this conflict.

precedents.case_name: Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited v Municipal Council of Broken Hill
